The duke of Edinburgh might undertake an extended course of training in aHarvard aircraft, but had asked that the position should be reviewed again when this 3tage of training was completed. He understood tha-this stage had now been reached, and that the Duke of Edinburgh was now due to fly an Oxford, a twin-engined training aircraftoTHE SECRETARY OP STATE PGR AJR said that it was also proposed that the Duke should fly a Harvard aircraft, under dualcontrol, at night.The Cabinet agreed that no objection need be raised to the duke 's undergoing this further stage of flying training. It wasimplicit in the Cabinefs original decision that he should complete the training which his instructors thought necessary to qualify him as a competent pilot. The Cabinet re-affirmed, however, their earlier view that the Duke of Edinburgh should not fly jet aircraft.
